awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building students' data literacy through the co-design of curriculum by mathematics and art teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to enact and study a process in which middle school teachers of mathematics and visual arts co-design and teach activities that combine math and art to teach data science. Many existing efforts to promote data literacy are grounded in mathematical concepts of central tendency and variation, and typically  are narrowly focused in single subject domains. Taking an art-based perspective on data science has the potential to promote student relevance, accessibility, engagement, reasoning, and meaning-making with data science. Moreover, visualization technology has advanced to a degree that the relation between the information in data and visual aesthetic can be leveraged easily. To explore the opportunity this offers, research on this project will examine how to equip teachers to develop such interdisciplinary pedagogical approaches to cultivate their students' data literacy. This exploratory project will provide support for 12 teachers during summer workshops and during the school year as these teachers implement their co-designed units in their classrooms. The work addresses the following questions: (1) How do we support effective co-design of data literacy units among art teachers, mathematics teachers, and researchers? (2) How are teachers able to use the unit materials in their classrooms to engage students in data literacy? And (3) How does an art-based approach support students' data literacy? Answers to these questions will build an understanding of how to support interdisciplinary curriculum design collaborations among researchers and teachers. They will also show how art-integrated, maker-oriented activities can support middle school learners' data literacy development; and how to design technologies that are accessible and powerful to teachers and learners in these interdisciplinary environments. 

Through summer workshops and year-round design collaborations, the project will iteratively design, test and refine four units for middle school classrooms, including activities, tools, and assessments, to promote students' data literacy. Data will be collected from co-design sessions as well as classroom-enactments, and will include observations, video/audio recordings, student- and teacher-generated artifacts, and pre and post assessments of students' knowledge and self-efficacy. Mixed methods analyses of these data, and syntheses of findings across participants, classroom enactments, and project years, will explore effective ways to support co-design among art teachers, mathematics teachers, and researchers; and the impact of art-integrated activities on students' data literacy.  This project will reach 12 teachers and their students across 6 New York city schools. By building capacity and knowledge about how to initiate and sustain teachers' interdisciplinary curriculum collaborations, the project will have broader impact. Refined project materials, including pedagogical approaches, toolkits and adaptable classroom activities, will be disseminated to facilitate classroom adoption by other educators who wish to undertake similar art-integrated data literacy curriculum design collaborations, and will thus ultimately broaden participation in data science among diverse youth within and beyond New York City.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to: (i) co-design and develop 1-2 week cross-curricular units for middle schoolers with art and math teachers across different schools, (ii) develop technological tools and curricular supports to promote art-based data literacy education within middle school classrooms, and (iii) implement, study, and refine the cross-curricular units and technology within each of the classrooms.

We co-designed and implemented four units that integrate math and the arts:

(1) Healthy Neighborhoods and Photovoice

Given the overarching question, “What makes a healthy neighborhood?,” students explored and critiqued data indicators of healthy neighborhoods (e.g., high school completion rates, food access, green space, life expectancy). Based on personal stories about their neighborhoods, they collected photos and stories of indicators they identified to be missing, and displayed these in a collective website (called Postcards from the Bronx) to counter the stereotypical story told of their neighborhoods. We observed that through their creative writing, students were able to draw connections between their personal experiences and the data they explored, and were eager to tell stories about their neighborhoods.

(2) Friendship and comics

Students explored the context and utility of friendships by surveying their own class and reflecting on data from a study conducted by the PEW Research Center. They then analyzed the data, graphed some of the data, and analyzed other researcher-made graphs of the data. The students then chose statistics they found interesting from the friendship data and developed a “data comic” that integrated the data and included inferences they made based on the data. Results from this initial implementation suggest that students found the friendship data engaging, and the use of comics helped students to use math in ways that they felt were relevant for their lives. Additionally, feedback from students suggests that through their exploration of the data, students reflected on and grew their own knowledge and socio-emotional skills related to adolescent friendships.

(3) Dance Unit

Students engaged in graph reading and in drawing inferences that they then translated into dance movements and sequences as part of their semester long project course. In groups or individually,  students explored graphs from self-identified themes of women’s rights, social media, minecraft, mental health, and animal populations. They then chose characteristics of the data and inferences from their analysis of the graphs to transpose into dances that they performed at an end of the year event in front of the rest of the school including teachers, administrators, parents, and their peers. Results from the initial implementation suggest opportunities for learners to use both data and dance to explore meaningful topics in ways that expanded their perspectives of the topics and at times engaged them in reflection on their identities. This implementation illustrates characteristics of data and graphs that learners chose to transpose into their dances.

(4) Time Use and Photojournalism

With the overarching question, “How does our time use relate to our mental health?” students explored data from the American Time Use survey, and reflected on how it does and does not reflect the time use of people of their own age. From teachers’ reflections, we learned that time use can be a personally engaging topic for students, in which they are able to draw connections to social justice issues.

New technology development

We piloted a web-based tool that allows students to express arguments from data in the form of memes. This work has begun to help us understand culturally-relevant new media for learners to reflect and communicate about specific aspects of data. Findings from piloting the tool in interviews with learners and with three teachers have informed iterations on its design, scaffolds for critical thinking about data through art and technology, new ways for engaging students in communicating about data, and an understanding of criteria that teachers use when choosing to incorporate technology-based tools into cross-domain classroom activities.

We anticipate that our findings provide insights for improving cross-domain co-design processes among teachers and researchers by analyzing across several artistic disciplines from comics, to dance, to photography, to physical and digital art, providing examples and illustrations of how other schools and researchers might similarly support data literacy learning and instruction, through cross-domain interdisciplinary learning and instruction.
